i've naturally been a night owl my whole life, but i actively work on being an early riser now. your body being up past 1/2am makes it crank out more cortisol, like you said. as someone with chronic pain, this makes it much worse because cortisol is putting more stress on your body, and we all feel like shit when we're stressed. i also think part of why i developed chronic pain in the first place has a lot to do with with my poor sleep habits (even if they are more natural to me). to combat that i do light therapy every morning which helps me set my REM cycle to one more beneficial for my health, and take the medicines i need when it's most ideal to take them (assistants with energy in the morning and early afternoon, sleepy meds in the early evening etc.). im still not very great at sticking to a good schedule at all, but im trying. and it's crazy how much more confident and happy i am when im waking up earlier and sleeping at a decent time. being a night owl doesnt mean something is wrong with you, but i would encourage people to consider looking into strategies that may help them transition into a healthier sleep schedule. staying up all night is, generally speaking, not very good for your health <3

We are a brainwashed 9 to 5 society. I don't know if the 9 to 5 was so that people can see the product, and as we are visual creatures,  corperations who own us see it better for business or what?  But, with the amount of overpopulation, we really need to think about distributing the amount of people being active during certain times. During the day at my work the parking lot is A-war zone!  It is noisy, there is a lot more carbon monoxide and brake dust pollution, and a lot of unnecessary anxiety from people trying to move around and dodge each other as they're going through the store.  We live in an over stimulated society, a rat race.  We are over stimulated visually and audibly when in heavy traffic, probably why peoples brains are being conditioned to dumb things down/not focus.  No one hardly uses their turn signals or looks in their mirrors anymore, they could give a shit less about who's around them or what is going on.  A waay higher risk for a car accident in my overpopulated city.  When I close and get off at night the parking lot is nearly empty, it is nice and quiet, and the air quality is much better. Way better for your blood pressure because you do not have to deal with all of that unnecessary chaos, pollution and anxiety. I guarantee you that you being active when all of these other people are blowing exhaust into eachothers faces, fighting eachother to the next red ligh, so they can buy more unnecessary bullshit  they don't need, "and will only end up in the eventual landfill," is NOT going to lead to a healthier life then someone that is active when less people are active.  Should be common sense.

Night Owl.....And I Love It : )

Covid 19 is cramping my style.
Stores are not open 24 hours because of it : ( That’s the best time to shop and get things done in 1/2 the time.

Less traffic.....you can get from point A to point B in no time : )

Shopping.....No lines and no bratty kids to deal with.

Grocery store shelves are stocked or being stocked for the AM rush.
So it’s easy to find what you need.

Laundry.....If you live in a House and You’re doing Laundry late at night it’s cheaper, utility wise. During the day.....AC units, Washing machine, dryers etc cost more to Operate because of the electricity demand.

Car Wash.....If you live in a House it’s easy to wash your Car late at night (quietly) and with no Sun the soap doesn’t dry out.

The Cleaners.....has a night drop box, where you can leave your clothes (again, no standing and waiting in line). You add a note in with your Cleaning Goodes that Specifies your needs....Press Only, Press & Clean, etc etc.

Hot Fresh Donuts.....
Donut shops open for business around 4:30 am with fresh bake goods.

Less stress.....Nights for the most part are very quite ( A dream come true) and cool. Perfect

Gas Stations are open.....no lines : )

Great time to relax and read a Book....

Exercise..... go out in your Garage and workout. You can do it quietly and you can even run if your backyard is clutter free.

Garage Facelift.....
I spent 6 months each night, Decluttering, organizing and painting the inside of my garage.

Bowling 24 Hours....and the price is super cheap.

So many things you can do at night. Night Owls end up meeting other Night Owls and we enjoy sitting Poolside with the fire pit going and chatting (quietly) until we hear the fricken Birds.....then it’s time to head in and go to sleep with dark out Curtains on the windows : )

LoL.....the Night Owls keep their lives full....with less drama and stress.

P.S. Most jobs pay more for working the night shift.

The Night Owl....1:34 AM : )

One thing everyone has to understand is that your sleep patterns will change throughout your life. When you're young you need naps, but you wake up early. Teenagers and those in their early 20s stay up late and sleeping late. This is also the time in your life when you can sleep the longest. 15-16 hours in a row! Store it like a camel and use it later. This doesn't really work the older you get. With time you sleep less hours, and you're more prone to naps. By the time you're old, you nap all the f**** time because they never sleep well or longer than a few hours at a time. This is pretty average for most people. Maybe you're a night owl now, but that can easily change. But if you try, actually really try, you can train your body to sleep the hours you tell it to.

I’m a Night Owl by my own conditioning and circumstances that lead me there. In high school I would do my homework from 2PM to about 7PM or later depending on the homework. But I wanted to play video games but we only had one Xbox One and I would let my brother play from the time he gets home (2 or 3PM) to his curfew (about 10PM or so). Naturally, I would then play but my curfew was at 12 AM or sometimes 11:30PM. This gave me a small amount of time of wind down and relax with some Siege or Overwatch (or whatever I would play). Eventually I got my own PC and stayed up as long as I wanted cuz I finally didn’t have to worry about taking turns or siblings. Plus, I can talk however I want at night without my mom going “watch your mouth” or “what did you say?”. But I had standards, so I go to bed around 2 AM or 3AM, I won’t let myself stay up past 5AM cuz I have things to do tomorrow. Also my mom won’t let me sleep in past 10AM or even 11AM (which is understandable). I can however go to bed late and wake up early if needed (which I did for sophomore year going to bed at 2AM and waking up at 6:30AM for school at 8AM). I think if I can get in the groove again, I can realistically and reliably run off 4 hours of sleep or so.

This concept of social jet-lag makes so much sense to me! I have insomnia. I have a hard time sleeping, at all. I am up all night and wake up early without hitting snooze or being grumpy. I often wake up before my alarm goes off and went years without even owning an alarm. I am kind of a morning person and a night person, but I think I'm closer to being a night person living in a morning person's world. I do make straight A's in school, though, but maybe that's because I pick classes that are later in the day. And I do get more energetic later in the day! All day long I feel like I'm falling asleep because I'm always so sleep deprived, but the closer I get to bedtime, the more awake I feel. It's frustrating! The weird thing is that I did try working overnight jobs and those did not seem to fit better for my schedule. I could not sleep very well in the daytime and I felt like I could not get anything done. It resulted in my feeling tired 100% of the time instead of 75% of the time. If my body is allowed to follow its own natural sleeping pattern, I sleep in a series of naps. I sleep for 3 or 4 hours, wake up for a couple hours, then sleep for another 3 or 4 hours, repeated however many times is needed. Basically, instead of an early bird or a night owl, I'm a cat.
The early bird gets the worm, but the second mouse gets the cheese.

Hereditary?? NO. How is it that the Greeks were so brilliant when it came to treating ailments/conditions/disorders? Because they utilized the person's astrological birth chart. There's real factual consistency in that certain planets affect us in certain ways, like how our skin produces vitamins when absorbing the sun, and the same way the moon effects the ocean tides. We, much like the planet itself, is made up of nearly 70% water. If the outer planets can so greatly influence LARGE MASSES of water on Earth, then how difficult would it be to influence us little droplets?? Not difficult at all. Astronomers always find out things decades (if not centuries) later that astrologers already knew. Documented. This is a science that needs to be considered in studies like this. For instance, if you're a Leo (or any fire & air sign), you're likely to function better during the day. Scorpios & Cancerians (water signs) are primarily night owls. "Hereditary." smh. Don't just pick up a book. Study this.

In my experience, there are those who have 'night owl' or 'early bird' predetermined for them (meaning they don't really adjust well to the opposite shift, ever), and there are those who can thrive in either with enough adjustment/consistency. Some must take the morning and others must take the night, but some are on standby and can be used wherever needed. I seem to be one of those, which is why this is even a theory to me. It seems the thriving is more full though, for those who have their schedules decided for them. It helps that they don't have to worry about having to switch everything around at any given time. It also seems the flexibility diminishes the longer the terms between shifting shifts. I mean, some flexibles deal with frequent switch ups better than others, while for the rest every six months/year or two might be more ideal. I'm thinking around 3-5 years might start impacting flexibility.

In my opinion this is not true, I started out as a night owl, because I had a graveyard shift at work, and I functioned fine, but my family hated me being up all night and keeping them up with my noises.

Then when I got a job that required me to wake up at like 5 in the morning, it was tough for me to adjust, but after a couple of months, I did adjust and now I can't stay awake at night and crash at about 9 to 10.

The body is not structured in any way, genes or otherwise to sleep at different times of the day, it is necessity that determines how we sleep and with patience and practice you can be either a night owl, or a early bird.

I’m definitely a night owl and I totally get the creativity thing. I love to write, but if I try to write in the morning, I’m very slow, I can’t find the right words, I make mistakes on my keyboard and just can’t get it quite ‘right’. My writing improves into the afternoon, with thoughts coming more quickly and I can transfer them onto the page much more easily. Fast forward to the evening, or even better, late at night, my creativity reaches its peak and when I’m writing, my brain is three sentences ahead of my fingers on the keyboard. As Rainbow Rowell perfectly described in her book ‘Fangirl’, writing like this feels like cycling downhill - you don’t have to do anything, the motion will take you, you just need to sit back and enjoy the ride.

I'm glad there's actually a scientific term for how shitty I felt when I had that temp job for three months that forced me to wake up at 6:45!! It wasn't only my mind that went downhill, but my skin and body as well. I was almost always bloated during the first half of the day so I usually kept my sweater on or wore loose shirts, and my skin started to breakout way more and my complexion became very dull to where I had to start piling on more makeup to make myself look good. Within 1 week of me sleeping in later after my contract ended my body went back to normal.
Also, I find that I can operate on less sleep when I'm allowed to sleep in. For example, going to bed at 10:45pm and waking up at 6:45am (8hrs of sleep) left me feeling heavily exhausted and shitty, however, going to bed at, say, 3:00am and waking at 9:30am (6hrs 30mins of sleep) leaves me feeling just fine.

The evolutionary stand point of this makes a lot of sense. I have never thought about it that way. Families needed to be asleep at different times for survival. I also think it is interesting that this trait can be inherited and that it was probably inherited from one of our earliest ancestors. Personally, I think I can be either. I like waking up in the morning (once I'm up and out of bed) because it makes me more productive and I feel like I get more errands and chores done. Plus waking up early allows me to take a nap without feeling guilty. I also feel that when i wake up earlier I am more motivated to knock homework out right away. However, I also love staying up late and sleeping in. I feel that I am more motivated to clean at night but also more relaxed. But in order for me to stay up throughout the night I have to have greater stimulation. For instance, it is really hard for me to stay up al night while watching a tv show. But if I'm on the web constantly searching and looking at stuff I can stay awake a lot longer.

CHALLENGE!  I highly doubt that wake up time is genetically linked.  It's far too easy to manipulate.  You can become a night owl or early bird on a whim.  I request instructions on how to read my genetic disposition for night owl or early bird from my genetic coding.  Anyone can alter this, and a dose of melatonin will aid in a swift alteration in your sleep schedule.  Any link between parent and child is likely due to upbringing (a child of night owls raised by early birds will more likely be an early bird than a night owl) <-- hypothesis, not conclusion.  And the consequences of both are more likely social links.  I've worked nights and stayed up into the wee hours of the morning with no trouble, I now wake up at 5am and bedtime at 9pm with no trouble.  I know which one feels more natural, but I demand to see your method of genetic solving to see if it matches with that.  You have a 50-50 shot at randomly guessing so it would not be proof either way... but if you claim it is genetic, you *MUST* know how to determine from a genetic code what that person.

But now that I think about it I never even tried to wake up early unless I had to and also never tried to go to bed early... so I associated waking up early with doing something that I had to do rather than wanting to, so that led me to believe that I'm not a morning person. I am a 56 year old night owl!!! All my life I got grief for staying up so late and wanting to sleep away the day!! Finally as a mother of 3 children all born within 5 years of each other, I was told by sisters and friends I would get USED to getting up early. Well I never did, even though I forced myself to go to bed at 11pm. any earlier attempts were futile. I still hated having to get up early. I decided to ask my doctor if this trait could be genetic, she said "Absolutely!!" As my father was the consummate night owl!!! And guess what, all of my children, now grown are night owls!! Per1........ Many scientists state that there are no known polymorphisms of the
human PER1 gene with significance at a population level that results in
measurable behavioral or physiological changes. This fact is a counter to the suggestion of the video...the suprachiasmatic nucleus...http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/gene/5187
physiological phenotypic trait variations that are caused by external or environmental factors that switch genes on and off and affect how cells read genes this is not genetics per se this is epigenetics........you should know this.

It's easy to change ur sleep schedule, to become a night owl just stay up late, then you'll wake up later, so then you'll go to sleep later.
To become an early bird, when "bedtime" comes around, skip it completely, so that the next day you'll be really tired, and you'll be able to go to sleep whenever you want to set your "bedtime". then set an alarm for the next day and then just go to sleep normally. Since you stayed up for a long time but didn't get enough sleep to make up for it, you are able to keep on going to sleep at the same time and if you keep waking up at the same time, you'll become an early bird that wakes up without an alarm.

I am going to have to say bullshit on the genetics. People can switch from being an early bird to a night owl, and vice versa, it is all determined by social behavior. The 9 to 5 thing is not what determines people's behavior as much as television formatting, movie times, sports events, etc.

It may be hereditary, because the child of one type is more likely to be raised with a similar attitude.

For some reason I have always had relationships with early birds and I always thought there was something wrong with me, and that I was lazy because I couldn't jump out of bed bouncing with energy the way they did in the morning. I'm a night-owl, and I come by it honestly - my parents are night-owls too. Until Grade 6, I thought it was normal to stay up till 1 am on a school night. But boy, living as a night-owl in a morning-lark world has taken its toll. It's become harder and harder to get away with loss of sleep, and harder and harder to cope with the typical 9-5 job. I work nights right now, but to my surprise, it's harder to cope with. I thought I'd be okay because my natural tendency (when I'm not working/on a stay-cation) is to fall asleep later and later until I'm going to bed at 4 or 5 or 6 am and going to sleep till 1 or 2 or 3 pm. However, it's a struggle to try to sleep in the daytime, never mind if you have to get shit done at the same time. I think it's because, after coming home from working a night shift, my body is undergoing mixed hormonal signals - it's energized with cortisol and just about tired enough for sleep at the same time, and also hungry for food. So I eat breakfast, and surprise, I can't sleep for a while. I'd probably be doing better if I had absolutely nothing that needed doing in the daytime, but of course, that's not possible, so I have to sacrifice precious sleep hours to get shit done.

On the bright side, sleep has suddenly become harder to ignore and more important to me as thing to guard and protect, with working nights. And one generally good thing about being a night owl was that it helped me to plow through many all-nighters for pretty well all of my English term papers in University. Well, if you can call that a good thing. :p

P.S. I rarely got bad grades in school. Usually B+s, A-s and As.

Did you know our sleeping patterns has drastically changed? In the past, instead of sleeping in one whole 8 hr chunk, we'd sleep in two shorter time chunks. In fact, we'd wake up in the middle of the night and stay awake for a couple of hours, before going back to sleep. All this changed when artificial light was introduced. So this idea of early bird and night owl is only very recent.

I think the problem with biological studies is that people instantly apply it to themselves, and are upset when it doesn't work out right. When these studies are done, the results are an aggregate of all of the collected data. There were certainly outliers in that data. A medical or biological result in a study doesn't necessarily imply that a particular person will experience life in the way the result implies. They might be an outlier.

For example, I don't think I'm a night owl or an early bird. I like staying up late, but I feel more productive if I wake up and go to bed early. I could just be an outlier.

How to change from being a night owl to an early bird (and still feel normal)
The idea is simple, the execution is not, so you should feel like shit while doing this but just fine when finished, not for the weak:
1.prepare about 1 week minimum, free of interruption, to yourself(you might need 2 weeks).
2.Every day you must stay up as late as possible, and everyday you must stay up later than the last day.(it wont work if you dont) don't drink coffee either, since i don't, I cant verify if this works for people that do.
3. Probably by the middle-end of the week you should notice that your sleeping pattern is backwards. For me I find myself waking up at night and sleeping through the day. That's good, cause you are halfway there.
4. Take the other half of the week/new week, and follow step 2 again. So if you are like me from step 3 (waking up at night sleep in the day), you need to stay up for 12hours + the time it takes to reach your target time. As in If I want to be an early bird, 10pm is my target time. So I'll wake up as usual (7pm) stay up for 12 hours -> (7am) + stay up until target time (10pm).
5. You should feel legit sleepy by your target time and if not, stay up another 12hrs and then sleep at the target time.
6.If you wake up early you passed the test and an elevated existence awaits you, if not you either failed somewhere, or you are genetically incapable of doing this.

I'm pretty sure the real reason most people are night owls is not so much preference but more that jobs/school all seem to be at times where if you actually go to bed at a good, early time, you'll end up having maybe 20 minutes of time to spend on your own. Can you please do more videos covering internal body clock?  Internal body clock is what determines if you will be a night owl or a morning person and not so much to do with genetics.  A good example is when a new born baby is out of a womb, it is very common for them to sleep during the day and awake during the night because the baby still thinks he/she is in the womb, and no affected by sun light.  Sleep doctors say people who tend to be night owls have messed up internal body clock, which are largely affected by sun light and those doctors use special lighting mimicking sun light so that your body internal clock can adjust to more socially acceptable active time, which is usually from 9 a.m. to 5 p.m.  Through personal experience I found that sleeping pills or anything is useless but internal body clock takes precedence over anything and I think it is a part of animals including human to be affected largely by sun light.
There are a lot of studies done in this area, because so many people are having sleeping problems, partly to do with more people using mobile phones and computers emitting those blue light affecting everyone's natural sleeping patterns, but not clear solutions are there yet.
I think this will be a great topic to cover in depth, and a lot of people will be interested to watch (after all everyone needs sleep).  You should cover these topics in series related to sleep section or something since you already did interesting videos covering sleep (how much sleep do you actually need...etc.).  Just an idea for you guys!
Again, thanks for enjoyable videos and look forward to more great videos.

This argument leaves out the natural adaptation of the body to different time zones. When a person transplants themselves into a new location with a different sunrise and sunset time, if they don't adjust their sleep patterns they can automatically be reconsidered a night owl or early riser. For example, person A, is an early riser and lives in San Diego, CA. Person B is a night owl and lives in Atlantic City, NJ. If they are transplanted without varying sleep schedules. Person A suddenly becomes a night owl and person B becomes an early riser. (I'm pretty sure my math worked but the point is understood). Worth noting for all the commenters calling "bullshit" - As this video explains, chronotype is varied on a spectrum from morningness to eveningness and everything between, but chronotype is also varied in terms of flexibility. Some people are very responsive to circadian rhythm markers like light and melatonin. Those people, despite their predisposition to being an "early bird" or "night owl," are able to employ flexibility in their sleep and wake times that allows them to maintain any schedule they choose. I'm a circadian rhythm disorder patient. That means that not only am I predisposed to be nocturnal, but I don't have the ability to maintain any other schedule. It causes chaos in my life because I don't have the ability to force myself to be societal to go to school/work; if my brain had its way I'd fall asleep at 6 AM and wake up at 3 PM. The concept of circadian rhythm "flexibility" is perhaps most apparent in shift work disorder. Take a nurse who needs to work nights. If she had her way, she'd work nights. But she can't, because her body signals for her to sleep at night. Her circadian rhythm causes disorder in her life because of its inflexibility. Bottom line, skeptical commenter, is just because you feel great after forcing yourself to sleep at 10 PM and wake up at 6 AM every day does not mean that the concept of chronotype or this video is "bullshit." Many people do not have the ability to regulate their sleep like you do.

If you don't like pointless babble, then move along. :)
Pointless Babble:
Every summer vacation for the past 8 or 9 years of my life have been battles of turning my sleep cycle back around before school/college started up again. I would stay up until sunrise and wake up before sunset... Eventually, though, my body would get sick of staying up so late, so it'd be almost as if it were "just in time" that I turned my cycle back around. But forcing myself to turn it around is such a tedious nuisance.
Eventually, I found out that my body doesn't like going to sleep until about 3 AM, so I don't like waking up until 11 AM... But there was a time in my life when I was sleeping in a "sunroom", and I actually fell asleep at 1:30 AM and woke up at 9:30 AM pretty consistently. Waking up that early (and feeling well-rested) always had a distinct, pleasant feeling to it. I don't know how to explain it. Anyway, nowadays, I actually aim to wake up at 10, since it's a great middle ground. I feel really lucky that I can choose my class schedule that best suits me and doesn't conflict with my sleeping schedule... but I worry for when I finally start my career. I really don't want to go back to feeling miserable like I did in high school, when I had to wake up at 6 every morning.

My sleep schedule adapts to my lifestyle. Problem is that this adaptation makes small changes over weeks and doesn't work well with rapid changes. Can't say that I've felt awake in the morning since I was a kid. As a teenager I stayed up until 2-3am and slept in class. Now I'm up to 4am-7am because I have nothing going on until late afternoon/evening. Mornings are the most boring time of day. It's when people slave away at this or that and have a long time to go before they can do something they want to do. Due to my psychological perspective on mornings, I naturally try to sleep through them. Night is when people unwind, when my mind is clear, and when I can do the things I want to do and even with the people I want to do it with if I so desire (because they aren't busy later in the day). 
As population continues to grow, I hope the developed world becomes 24hrs. That means everything is operational at night as it is during the day. That would mean more work and more money. As late as the 1900s there were people without electricity. Without fake lighting to keep us up after dark, our species would have adapted to earlier mornings. Since first world countries developed before this time, work days became the norm. However, now that we can live just as well during the night as we can during the day there is no reason to favor daytime hours.

My diurnal cycle, or circadian rhythm, is about 25 hours, but it has varied from 20 to 40 in the last few years. As a late teen I managed to stay awake for many days. Mostly due to highly interesting research subjects or video games, my two longest times being due to Ultima Online:6 days 7 nights awake straight and World of Warcraft: 5 days 6 nights awake straight. However, most of my 48 hour+ periods of restlessness have been due to all the fascinating topics I've learned in physics and other sciences and even some political, economic or historical topics.

I'll stop staying awake abnormally long when people stop making new things to learn and do, or I just die. Which, the latter being more likely to occur before I hit 50 given my heavy intake of nicotine and caffeine and my lack of personal hygiene.

The way I see it, there are billions of back up copies of me on this planet, every second that one shuts down, two are made, so one copy, me, will not go unreplaced.

I really admire the things you've all done though while I've had the chance to exist.

Thank you, for bringing me online and letting me observe the state of things on this planet, while I had the chance.

Please do continue to make more of yourselves but don't forget to nurture your new humans, throughout their lives. Stay in communication, share your thoughts and love every one of yourselves you get the chance to interact with.

I'm not sure I believe in the whole early bird vs night owl thing. I mean I've had periods during spring break when I was younger where I would stay up for say 18 hours, then sleep 8. If you continue that long enough, night owl becomes early bird. It's all relative I guess. Depending on what I'm doing, I can adjust my internal clock to either. If I know I have an important meeting, exam or test coming up, I'll adjust my schedual so that I wake up a few hours earlier, keep doing that for a week and you'll be an early bird, but if I'm on vacation, all the fun happens after midnight and I'll be sure to stay up late. It's all about discipline, people who are proclaimed "night owls" are procrastinating or worried about something, keeping them up longer than they should, depraving them of sleep. While the early bird might just have an easier time falling asleep.

Let's say you put people under ground for two months. No referance of day and night. No clock to keep track. No work to do. I think you'd see whatever group of people you put down there, sooner or later all would follow the same sleep schedual, regardless of being night owls or early birds.

I do found myself in quite a lot of these points.
I'm a nightowl myself. I was born 10pm, and when I was a little kid, my mom couldn't get me to sleep before 10pm. When I went in kindergarten, I actually used the morning to get into a hidden place, lay down and sleep, instead of interacting with the others (sadly, my kindergartners didn't even noticed my absence...), making my mom wondering why I'm always so fit and refreshed after kindergarten.
But I also remember a time where I got up early on weekends without troubles to watch morning cartoons. Overall, doring the first years of school, I managed that sleeping rythm fine. But the older I got, the harder it was for me to wake up in the mornings and the harder it became to go to bed early. In the end, constant bullying in school gave me all the good reasons not to care about school anymore, and I stayed awake till 2am, slept a few hours, tried not to fall asleep during class (didn't always worked out) and slept a bit when I came home again.
Today, I can shuffle my time as I want, which is a big plus. I go to bed at 6am and stand up around 12am - 1 pm. Some years ago, I tried to get a "normal" shedule, when my boyfriend moved in. Went to bed around midnight, stood up around 6am. It went fine for a few months, but about 3 months later, I completely broke down. I couldn't get fully awake until 12am, and I got a nervous breakdown. I then adjusted my times to the time today, which gave me a huge benefit again.
And I do admit, social life can be very harsh and stressful because of that. Especially when you have to balance appointments with doctors, banks, or your government agency.
It's even worse, when you live in a country, where 24/7 opened shops are not the norm ;D

So, I don't want this gene anymore. I feel like shit when I'm awake at night, and I'm addicted to sleep when I have been awake at night. I prefer to be diurnal, but I can never keep a diurnal routine, even if I absolutely have to. I love being awake during the day, even though I spend all of my free time at this very computer. And when I have been awake during the day, sleep is practically impossible to achieve for the first 4 hours that I'm lying in the dark. And then I wake up 4 hours later, sleeping through my alarms (plural and yet, I still don't wake up), only to slink back into a nocturnal routine within another day or two, no matter how much I wish I wouldn't.

That said, I can spend 12 hours awake feeling shitty, and 16 hours asleep (what's that? More than 24 hours? So?) feeling great in a nocturnal routine, but it always balances itself out so that I will never cycle between nocturnal and diurnal without me actually doing stuff to make sure I do cycle between them, such as staying up all night and all day, then crashing at the end of the second day, only to wake up at the start of the third day, in a diurnal routine that will only last a maximum of a week. In a diurnal routine, I can spend 14-16 hours awake feeling great, which is normal enough, but only get 4 hours sleep within the final 8 hours of the day feeling shitty.

I prefer to get enough sleep to not be tired, but I prefer to actually want to be awake. This shit is so bass ackwards.

I've gone through both so i can give personal experience on both haha
One time i was an early worm, slept early, at a good time, I was INSANELY happy and bouncy first thing in the morning and felt fantastic, but by the end of the day i was exhausted and couldn't wait to sleep.
Then i went through a phase for about a year where i slept 0-2 hours a night, 3 if i was lucky, I was insanely slow and sluggish all day and did worse in school, I ate less, depression became a thing, and augh, not good, but then also i got used to it in the end and could work with it, so it wasn't OVERLY bad after a while.
But now, I'm caught in between, my depression factors my sleep and for a few months it wasn't so bad and i slept at about 10:30-11 most nights and woke up at 5:30-6:30 depending on the day due to college, and I was fine, all day and all night i was good, but sadly the depression came back again and now i am up till 12-3 am, I'm waking at 6:30 now as i no longer need to wake at 5:30 for certain days, so those days i wake up around 8-9 typically, one problem has occurred, I wake very slow and groggy and grumpy, I can barely walk due to back pains being worse when I'm tired, I am normally always disorientated in one way or another, and slowly as the week goes on, I feel extremely exhausted, I have no motivation, I get a bad attitude, and yeah, not nice XD BUT, it's not so bad to the point where my work is being majorly affected and my attitude unlike before, like i do have days where i will not work at all, or very poorly, but yeah, otherwise this sort of in between is working for me right now on the most part!

I keep seeing comments on choosing and adapting to a set sleep schedule. Man, I wish it were that easy for me. I've been battling my sleep schedule for years, even before puberty. I'll do whatever I can to be tired and go to bed by say 11 P.M., and set several alarms to wake up at 7 A.M. Never lasts long. My body eventually says "I'm not tired" when I go to bed, and I don't get sleepy until 5-8 A.M. It seems I've gotten the best sleep when my sleep schedule has me going to bed when the sun rises. It's when I feel the most well rested and energized. Maybe because I actually feel kind of sleepy when exposed to lots of sunlight (doesn't make sense to me, but it happens).
It'd be an interesting world if we haven't set a 9 A.M.-5 P.M. Mon-Fri kind of schedule for most jobs and careers. We could have more freedom to follow our personal circadian rhythms.

I have a condition called DSPS - Delayed Sleep Phase Syndrome. A lot of adolescents have the same thing but the difference for me is that mine is permanent. Even though I'd be able to get my 8 hrs of sleep easily, I don't get them because my biorhythm makes me fall asleep later, but my life still wants me to wake up at the same time as other people.
You 'get used' to less sleep but it still screws up basic abilities; it's harder to think of certain words, you get physically tired faster, you lose concentration faster, ...

For all the people who tend to fall asleep later than most people, but around the same time every day (and not just once every now and then ^^) I advise you to go see a specialist. There's lots of ways to give you the rest you need even if you have trouble falling asleep. And for all the kids who think less sleep is cool, don't overdo it, there's too many downsides to that ;)

I've always preferred to be awake at night. Not only do I feel more awake during the night, but my body just doesn't like to sleep then. In fact, when I force myself to sleep at night, even after 8 hours, I wake up without feeling very rested at all. 

The main issue I have is that my sleep pattern isn't consistent. A quick example. I work night shifts. I'll get back from work at about 4 AM. I also bike to work and back, doing manual labor. When I get back, I'm still pretty awake and energized from that exercise, adrenaline and so on. And of course, I don't want to sleep as soon as I get back, I'll stay up until at least 5 or 6 AM. This can be my routine for a while, but after a couple weeks, I'll notice I don't get tired enough to sleep until at least a few minutes later, each day. Until I notice I'm only getting tired at 7 am, or 8 am, and it keeps getting worse, until I find myself sleeping at 1 PM and waking up at 9 PM, and even for a night owl, that is rather depressing.

Eventually to fix this I have to pull an all-nighter... well, I guess an all-dayer is more accurate for this situation. It's very difficult to do when you have to work later, but I'll do it, and manage to reset my sleep pattern back to the default, only for this cycle to repeat, yet again.

It's very annoying.
